questions.question: Which statement describes a feature of a zone-based policy firewall?

options.text: The router security posture is to allow traffic unless explicitly blocked.
It does not depend on ACLs.
It uses a flat, non-hierarchical data structure making it easier to configure and troubleshoot.
All traffic through a given interface is subject to the same inspection.

questions.explanation: A zone-based policy firewall (ZPF) does not require the use of complex ACLs. By default, traffic traveling between zones is blocked unless specifically permitted.

questions.question: Which statement describes a zone when implementing ZPF on a Cisco router?

options.text: A zone is used to implement traffic filtering for either TCP or UDP.
A zone establishes a security border of a network.
A zone is used to define security policies for a unique interface on the router.
Only one zone can be attached to a single interface.

questions.explanation: Zones establish the security borders of a network. A zone defines a boundary where traffic is subjected to policy restrictions as it crosses to another region of the network.

questions.question: Designing a ZPF requires several steps. Which step involves defining boundaries where traffic is subjected to policy restrictions as it crosses to another region of the network?

options.text: establish policies between zones
design the physical infrastructure
determine the zones
identify subsets within zones and merge traffic requirements

questions.explanation: The first step in designing a ZPF is determining the zones, which involves separating the network into zones that establish security borders.

questions.question: Which statement describes one of the rules that govern interface behavior in the context of implementing a zone-based policy firewall configuration?

options.text: An administrator can assign an interface to multiple security zones.
By default, traffic is allowed to flow among interfaces that are members of the same zone.
By default, traffic is allowed to flow between a zone member interface and any interface that is not a zone member.
An administrator can assign interfaces to zones, regardless of whether the zone has been configured.

questions.explanation: Interfaces that belong to the same zone allow traffic flow between them by default. An interface can belong to only one zone.

questions.question: Which three statements describe zone-based policy firewall rules that govern interface behavior and the traffic moving between zone member interfaces? (Choose three.)

options.text: Traffic is implicitly prevented from flowing by default among interfaces that are members of the same zone.
Pass, inspect, and drop options can only be applied between two zones.
Interfaces can be assigned to a zone before the zone is created.
If traffic is to flow between all interfaces in a router, each interface must be a member of a zone.
An interface can be assigned to multiple security zones.
To permit traffic to and from a zone member interface, a policy allowing or inspecting traffic must be configured between that zone and any other zone.

questions.explanation: If traffic is to flow between all interfaces, each must be in a zone. Policies (pass, inspect, drop) are applied between zones. Traffic flow requires a policy between different zones.

questions.question: In ZPF design, what is described as the self zone?

options.text: the router itself, including all interfaces with assigned IP addresses
a predefined cluster of servers with configured interfaces
a predefined cluster of routers with configured interfaces
the outward facing interface on the edge router

questions.explanation: The self zone is the router itself and includes all the IP addresses assigned to the router interfaces.

questions.question: How does ZPF handle traffic between an interface that is a zone member and another interface that does not belong to any zone?

options.text: drop
inspect
pass
allow

questions.explanation: If one interface is a zone member and the other is not, the resulting action is to drop the traffic regardless of whether a zone-pair exists.

questions.question: Which statement describes a factor to be considered when configuring a zone-based policy firewall?

options.text: An interface can belong to multiple zones.
A zone must be configured with the zone security global command before it can be used in the zone-member security command.
The router always filters the traffic between interfaces in the same zone.
The classic firewall ip inspect command can coexist with ZPF as long as it is used on interfaces that are in the same security zones.

questions.explanation: A zone must be created (using the zone security global command) before it can be assigned to an interface.

questions.question: Which statement accurately describes Cisco IOS zone-based policy firewall operation?

options.text: A router interface can belong to multiple zones.
Router management interfaces must be manually assigned to the self zone.
The pass action works in only one direction.
Service policies are applied in interface configuration mode.

questions.explanation: The pass action allows traffic only in one direction.

questions.question: When a Cisco IOS zone-based policy firewall is being configured, which two actions can be applied to a traffic class? (Choose two.)

options.text: forward
drop
hold
copy
inspect
log

questions.explanation: The three actions that can be applied to a traffic class in ZPF are inspect, drop, and pass.

questions.question: In what step of zone-based policy firewall configuration is traffic identified for policy application?

options.text: configuring class maps
creating policy maps
defining zones
assigning policy maps to zones

questions.explanation: Traffic is identified for policy application during the configuration of class maps.

questions.question: When configuring a class map for a zone-based policy firewall, how is the match criteria applied when using the match-all parameter?

options.text: Traffic must match all of the criteria solely defined by ACLs.
Traffic must match at least one of the match criteria statements.
Traffic must match all of the match criteria specified in the statement.
Traffic must match the first criteria in the statement.

questions.explanation: The match-all parameter dictates that packets must meet all the match criteria specified to be considered a member of the class.
